Entry.4:
Luxor:- Karnak, Tombs of Queens

Medinet Abou

Collossi

Luxor Hotel.
Entry.5:
5.45 train Luxor to Edfu. Edfu Temple.

2.15 train to Assonan

Saw dam

Grand Hotel
Entry.6: Donkey ride up Nile some 4 or 5 miles, to Philae in boat.11am to Luxor
Entry.7:
Karnak before bkfast to Tombs of Kings over mountain to other tombs.

Luxor Hotel. Monstapha`s 

Train to Cairo
Entry.10: Moved Bde to Heliopolis. Marched through the cemetery area of some miles, past the Citadel down Sharin Mahommet Ali, the Governorat, Warzor, Alakassin, S to Heliopolis.
Entry.11: To Meadi in evening and saw early arrivals of 5th,6th and 7th LH Regts and
Entry.14: Bde scheme out to the Kanka sand drifts.
Entry.15:
Lt Weir with reinforcements reports arrival at Abassia Reinf.camp.

Dinner continued met several new
Entry.16: and Onslow. Dinner with R Horden and W Charlie. Dance at Mrs Devonshires.
Entry.17: to town in afternoon for drive round Rhoda Island and past zoo.
Entry.18: Saddled and left at 3 - for outpost line from hut in NE direction. Dug trenches till 12 midnight – returned camp 2.15 am.
Entry.19: Out with NZ Mtd Rifle Bde and inspect the trenches N of old Suez railroad.
Entry.20: Divisional scheme 7 am to Abbassia then to old Heliopolis and El Marg returning 6 pm.
Entry.21: To Barrage – where the main canals that feed the Delta branch from the Nile beautiful gardens with trolley rails and rides along all the principal walks.
Entry.22: Divisional field firing to Abassia Barracks Manchester ASC officers mess in evening – at invitation of Capt Ison
Entry.23: Dinner at Continental with Capt Green and Major Glasgow. Mrs. S M Gandy and Miss Gordon Smith. Dancing afterwards at the Hotel. Met Hyman and Fuller for 1st time since their arrival.
Entry.24:
In camp

15 Mon

Caught 7 am train with Bdr A Cols of 2nd and
Entry.25: Rgts to Kantara examined the advcd post 1m out where fight was. To Tussum and Serapeum by boat; saw several Turks remains. Back to Temalia and returned camp 12 midnight.
Entry.26:
Field off. Of day

Visited Abassika Detention Barracks. 151 Aust and NZ soldiers in. Lts Weir and MacMillan joined with 51 reinforcements.
Entry.27: Capt Ison came to mess afterwards went to Helipolis House – met Col Everett and Genl Douglas the E.Lancs Div`l Cmdr.
Entry.28: brigade training. Outposts along Taufigia Canal from Obelisk to El Birka,
Entry.29: Divisional training – attack on Inf FA and LH along Old Suez Road. Saw and killed 1st snake same colour as sand.
Entry.30:
Birthday

Col down at S Canalso stayed in camp. Toasted H.M. in mess at night.
Entry.31:
In camp’

Short byc ride into Heliopolis in afternoon and broke chain.
Entry.32:
Regt. training on allotted area.

Lecture in evening by Gen Cunliffe Owen from front.
Entry.33: The following days are a succession of Regimental training schemes and drills, varied by khamaseens, only few evenings off.
Entry.34: Getting warmer but still a little cold in early morning.
Entry.35: In a Khamseen to Sakkira with Wal Cox, misses Claydon and Hedges. Car to San Giovanni. Ferries over the rivers. Donkeys to Marrick and train back to Cairo from Bedrasheen
Entry.36: Nose inspected by Dr Barratt (Major) at Heliopolis Hosp. x rays – very painful after for some days so do not ride.
Entry.37: A Sqn go by road to Barrage to practise crossing rivers by means of ropes endless.
Entry.38:
Went by train to Barrage with Dr Fullerton. Had tea – and dinner at Mr Smith the chief engineer of the Barrage System

A Sqn swam horses and B arrived per road.
Entry.39:
Saw B Sqn AHQ swim their horses

Gardens very full in afternoon had a quiet loaf about and took some snaps

C Sqn arrived
Entry.40:
Rode back with Clark, on Merrington`s horse, from Barrage – arrived 1.30 pm road all had cultivation as far as Shukra. Took photo of village St and sent home.

The big riot in the Wazh-el-Birka from 4.30 to 9.30 PM
Entry.41: The feast of Shem-el-Messim for the breathing of the zephyrs. Owing to a severe sandstorm or kamseen the Regt got 200 yds from camp and did not reach the cultivation along Gabal and Siraquis canals we were ordered to. I left camp 5 minutes after them and searched for 1½ hours then stayed with LHFA in cultivation. The Egyptians this day merry make in the fields and all is holiday.
Entry.42: day of the turn of the seasons. Tents were filled with sand etc.
Entry.44: New brown horse bad attack of sand colic.
Entry.45:
Horse had 3 injections of stigmine

Clarke and Gwillian up all night with him.
Entry.46: Horse little better. Clarke up all night
Entry.47: Route march of the Bde through Heliopolis, Abassia, Railway Sq, cut off a corner along Boulac, to Kasr-el-Emi, Vieux Caire, Babs-el-Youn to Meadi, Dined with Geo Onslow. Boxing at
Entry.49: Left Bivouac at Meadi about 7.30 am and rode to Helwan. March discipline much better. Native children fairly cheeky. Saw some of the Turk prisoners at Toura. Rode past San Giovanni up to Helouan. A bivouached behind the Tewfik Palace Hotel.
Entry.50: The Regiment crossed the two arms of the river Nile – and island between, on 3 punts towed by a launch, on the 1st or widest ea holding 25 horses. A by 2 punts on ropes on Bedrashin side. All went to Sakkara in between. Took from 8.30 am to 8.10 pm; no break.
Entry.51: 2nd Regiment do their crossing and the
Entry.52: remain in Bivouac behind the Tewfik Palace Hotel. I ride to Sakkara with Regtl HQ and the drivers who did not cross before, very good concert in Hotel grounds in evening by the Bde. Mde Spunger played opera and the Italian consuls wife
Entry.53: Message to report to Board to sit on the damage done in the Wazir area of good Friday. So took the three horses and Gwillian and rode home from Helouan,had lunch with Col Cox at Meadi en route. This was the day of A and NZ landing.
Entry.54:
Reported and found myself next senior to the President Lt Col Fallows T.D.

Gallipoli doings of others. The landing has achieved under very heavy fire, some of the earlier boats never reaching land at all. The navy mistook the landing place by half a mile N, the place they were going to being
Entry.55:
Practically impregnable. Directly they touched shore they jumped into water, some over their heads. As they touched the shore they fixed bayonets and drove Turks up and over the precipitous heights for about 4 m. Officers and men mixed. Men did not wait for orders but fought as seemed most natural in general line. Had to retire to position we found ourselves on arrival later as no support. Several thousand casualties.

Examination of hills show an almost impossibility of advance. Kit and dead everywhere. Heroic stands for 2 or 3 days without water and food
Entry.56: On the board to assess damages for the Wazir riot. Lt Col Fallows TD leaves and I am appointed president.
Entry.57:
On the Board. Held at Soldiers Club.

Wounded just beginning to arrive at Heliopolis.
Entry.58:
On the Board.

Organizing hospitals all over Cairo, including Luna Park
Entry.59:
Col Meredith away for a holiday on the Nile !!

Visited hosp to see Cl Edwards and Sgt Fizpatrick and others.
Entry.62: Bringing a portion of the Board work to a section completion in case we are to go
Entry.63: Warned we be leaving about Sat night without horses so worked hard and finished 33 of the cases and wrote and signed reports. From 9am to 8pm without leaving the room.
Entry.64: Told that I was to take the regiment and we were to leave Sat night. Short notice.
Entry.65:
Left camp at 11.30 pm and marched with heavy packy to Helmieh entrained at 4.20 for Alexandria.

9th. Issued with puttees and infty pants. Embarked on DEVANHA with 30 on the Kingstonian. Fine weather.
Entry.66: O/b the P and O SS Devanha are Col Chauvel and staff 1st and 2nd regts, several infantry details, wounded officers returning and various officers to replace etc. Also the carts and blankets of bns that had come in her originally. heard many details of the fight.
Entry.67: At sea – no other ships in sight. Passed some beautiful islands like Saros and Lemnos.
Entry.68: Anchored at Helles point on Cape Hellas and watched the shelling. Passed within 1 mile from SS Scotia but could not raze G.Randell, moved up coast and anchored ANZAC Bay near Katta Tepe.
Entry.69: Landed beginning 6am. Went on a destroyer about 400 of us. Then into lighters holding about 80 each. Dowling E S struck by shrapnel in the mouth . Waited an hour or two (1st and 2nd Regts.) and then marched to Monash valley and bivouacked. The bullets fling all night 6` above. Visited Quinns post and Popes post, awake all night
Entry.70: At 8 am visited Popes Post to relieve him – completed at 1.30 pm. Continuous firing over trenches night and day till 17-18th. Divided post into 3. Precipitous clayey shale with much to do to dig into proper cover. Up all night.
Entry.71:
Firing all day. HQ 2nd LH had suffered a great deal form bombs throwing. A at night arranged bayonet attack on Turkish trenches on Quinns extension. 70 lef and 46 were casualties. Major Graham K and most officers wounded. Failure to some extent. I had Regt up all night and moved them from L to R as reports came on telephone

c
Entry.72: Early at midnight the noise became abso deafening every rifle poured rapid and bombs were thrown one pre 2 minutes on Q hill. Subsided at 5 am. Recommended Crisp for bravery in gully of Deadmans Hill. Donovan of Q. Up all night
Entry.73: Same noise all day and night, a hand or head over the trenches immediately hit. Many escapes and clothing pierced. At night`1 Cpl and 4 men of 16 tried to rescue a machine gun the dead and scattered rifles and tools on Razorback or Deadman`s hill; did not get Smell from dead very trying. Kit littered all over the hills and valleys.
Entry.74:
I turned Regt out

About 12.30 the enemy`s fright died down a little but an attack had been prepared for at 3.50 am with cries of Allah the whole A and NZ posts were rushed. We drove

 off some 50, killing many some in our trenches, our 1st hand to hand fight. Nichols arm hurt.

They tried in front of Quinn`s and Courtenays posts till 10am and gave up. Officially we are told they had 2000 dead and 5000 wd. Relieved during a heavy fire fight at 3 pm by
Entry.75:
LH. 

I am hit in the calf but by richochet only and cary on. 

Today killed 11, Wd 17 (taken away) 

Lined inner defence trenches at night.
Entry.76: After 6am went into bivouac in valley. Bullets lob in our dugouts and sound very dangerous. Casualties
Entry.77:
2 killed 4 wounded. Armistice white flag by Turks. We lined trenches at night 

21 Friday

Went to Anzac Cove for a swim – 1st bath since landing and 1st time boots and socks off. Casualties in valley 4 wounded.
Entry.78: Fairly quiet day. We landed and sent up 2 Japanese bombs howitzers. High general led on to our beach for armistice. Cas 1 killed and 2 wounded. Wrote a letter to M.V. no incidents. Turk dead piled in acres. Rained
Entry.79: rain since leaving Str of Victoria
Entry.80:
Fairly quiet day. No casualties from sniping a record – but the usual 1 or 2 sick sent back

24 Mon

Armistice from 7.30 am to 4.30pm for enemy to bury their dead. Each side buried those half way between ea others trenches.

Counted 51 dead opp of post that C Sqd was at in various stages. Saw Germans Saw sev curios. Many of enemy
Entry.81: Wore our equipment. Few Australians and NZ all past recognition and removal.
Entry.82:
Down to Anzac Cove with Clark for the swim I have daily. Had b

reakfast after coming out, on the beach. HMS Triumph blown up by a torpedo off the shore.
Entry.83: Oceassional stands to arms. Swim under bullet fire. Had 1 killed and 2 wounded by shots down Monash Valley.
Entry.84:
same as yesterday.

Working parties. Swim

2 wounded today. Stood to arms from 4.30 pm to 2.30 am as Turks massing at left head of Monash Gully.
Entry.85:
Same. Road to beach very dangerous from machine gun fire and bullets.

About 40 men hit by Turks marksmen while drawing stores from supply depot, before 10am.Weather warm 

I man of ours wounded.
Entry.86: Got up at 3.10 am and at 3.30 heavy mine explosions and the Turks shelling bombing and machine guns; they rushed Quinns Hill and took trenches; reported L-Cpl Grimson`s took 12 prisoners himself and joined the trenches again after searching in them for Turks
Entry.87: Some 60 of 10th ALH and some 30 or 2 NZ inf rushed out from Quinns to pull down the sandbag building in front and fill in the trench only 4 of 10 who were not casualties. Result more successful than not. No swim.
Entry.89:
Yesterday quieter. I placed C Sqd on Popes Post in right section.

Swim in morning. Met Clarence Pyke.

1 June Tuesday 

Quiet last night but we were to have made an attack on Quinns and Popes. Found 1 off 1 sgt 2 cpl and 24 men as picquet in NZ Valley. 4 wounded
Entry.90:
Brought A and B Sqdns to Popes and with C filled the two left sections, in 3 

Sqns. Quiet night.

2 wounded. Lt Birch of
Entry.91:
killed.

3 Thursday

On Popes.

Generally quiet. Lce Corpl Grimson in charge of the sniping posts. With 6 others
Entry.93:
On Popes Hill

L Cpl Grimson wounded. Lce Cpt Keyes put in charge.
Entry.95:
On Popes hill

Letter from Grandell
Entry.96: On Popes Hill. Went to see G. Randell on Sicilia. Had lunch. Found the Cpl – R Skone – a cousin. Very pleasant and clean on boat. Came back with Gen.Godley.
Entry.97: Relieved at 9 am by 3rd Regt LH. Retired to Valley on West of Popes and organized bivouac areas etc. Water arrived from ships and is stored in tanks. No casualties in Monash Valley owing to enemy snipers marked by our own. No casualties.
Entry.98: At work on the road in our bivouac up the watercourse of the valley. About 10 to 15 feet wide.
Entry.100: In valley bivouac. Penetrated gully up hill found a night outpost of the Turks – brought back some equipment curios.
Entry.101:
In valley bivouac.

Padre Merrington and also padre Green held communion services opposite Regt Hdqu dugout. Latter was the 1st had seen here – about 43 communicants.
Entry.102:
In valley bivouac

15 Tuesday

In valley bivouac

June 1915

16 Wed

In valley bivouac.

Capt Lawries – A Sqn went on to right of Popes Hill in lieu of a squ of 2nd LH. While 2nd relieved 3rd LH.

SS Sicilin left Anzac. Shelling beach.
Entry.103:
In valley bivouac.

Shelling beach again some swimmers being nearly caught.
Entry.104:
Wrote to G.S. for supplies from Cairo – sent PT 200and list of tobacco etc. and food.

L.C.Bland hit.
Entry.109: Regt goes to Popes .Quiet in front
Entry.110:
On Popes.

No attacks of consequence.

Sgt Barry hit.
Entry.115:
Bourke and Monaghan killed. Turks rushed down gully after reverse on Walkers Top – about 200 – 250 of them. Broadbent carried 1 gun to left and we drove them back easily with many casualties about 10.30 Pm on.

4 wounded. Nash of
Entry.118:
To hospital ship Sicilia due to indig, dysty, and general weakness.

Regt took up bivouac at Section H.Q. Monash Valley.

1 July Thursday

On Sicilia.
Entry.119: On Sicilia. The wind made the beach landing too dangerous and the bringing of wounded on to Sicilia too difficult. She was to go to Lemnos, but they could not land me nor transfer me to the Neuralia.
Entry.120: Arrival Lemnos 40 miles away. Huge Brit and Fr navies in . After midday moved into the port and was landed at 5.30 pm.to No 1 Hosp, No food till 10 to 10 pm. Lt Green of Inniskilling Fusiliers ,Ealing London
Entry.121: Walked with Capt Williams and Lane out to a Greek village 2½ m. out. Villages and houses poor. Lunched on hopbeer sardines and bread. At 3.30 went on b Arragon and later on to Prince Abbas with 4 others for Anzac
Entry.122: At 11am getting in to Lock Esk from Pr. Abbas an enemy submarine appeared about 5o yds off and the two boats parted hurriedly – Major Rutledge having Knox`s box – went to Imbros and lost it there – I went to till 4.30 when got on Lock Esk again – ashore 11.30 pm and thence to bivouac.
Entry.123: At 5 am went to beach – rung up for Rutledges batman and he came and took charge of his goods.
Entry.124:
Major Rutledge returned but had to leave Max`s box on Prince Abbas.

B Sqn went into Popes Post.
Entry.129:
Ditto

Cas Thomlinson killed going for the mail on beach.
Entry.130: Lt Edmonds with 123 others (8 old and 118 reinforcements) arrived
Entry.131:
Popes Post

Todays state 50 officers and 417 other ranks to which add Padre, M.O., and 3 AAMC
Entry.132:
Popes Post shelled

3 wounded on Post
Entry.133:
wounded on Beach.

ANZ MO attached vice Wells
Entry.134:
Capt Fraselin arrived and NZ dr went

Application for temporary Lt Col returned not granted. Col Meredith still in command and can be brought here at a moments notice.
Entry.135:
Came down off Popes went into Bivouac in gully

Preparing defence of gully
Entry.136: Arranged C Squ on Hill Station – A Sqn in gully and Tinsons post and B Sqn in reserve.
Entry.137: Last days of Ramadan – expecting attack of Turks.
Entry.138: Went on destroyer Colne with Col Stoddart and 2 NZ officers to view the coast towards Suvla Point – ES Sutton and Sgt Gregory and 1 or 2 others wounded swimming
Entry.139: A chill from being out at sea yesterday
Entry.140: Influenza or fever. Handed regiment over to Capt Laurie as could not leave dugout
Entry.141: Carried down to beach and put on board Hosp ship REWA
Entry.142:
REWA

Gen Birdwood in /bd got him to assist that I be transferred to next ship instead of being taken away. Rewa fever
Entry.143:
Moved 0/bd Gloucester Castle and anchored still off Anzac

Col Rowell came 0/b
Entry.146: Transferred to Sicilia, from the G Castle which went to Alex.
Entry.147: Not well enough to get up but had wanted to get ashore for impending advance
Entry.148:
Sicilia

During night English troops landed at Suvla Burnu and there was severe fighting all day. Saw our troops on part of 971 west side.
Entry.149: Spent last night Imbros. Back to Anzac. Thence to Mudros
Entry.153: Arrived Alex midday. Left by Hospital train for Cairo 8 pm got there at 12 midnight.
Entry.154: At No 2 Austr Gen Hosp, Gezireh
Entry.155: Geof came in. Also Col M
Entry.156: Got up and went to see Capt Hore.
Entry.158: Town had lunch with Col M and saw several friends.
Entry.159: Lunch at La Toscana with Geoff.
Entry.160:
To Helmieh and saw Col M and reinforcements 50 leave for Anzac. 12th Regt and Geof F Weir in hospital.

Mrs.Gandy and Miss Nunn called.
